tweets.text:
100-opinion tweet challenge accepted. 
https://t.co/N7n6SlSUwO

1. Sensory experience is wild, in the sense that it gives you as direct as possible an interaction with nature. It can be outside the little box of civilization that mediates most interaction between humans and the natural world (like in this diagram) https://t.co/E7ru03Acto
2. The strong version of the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis is clearly wrong. I experience counterexamples to it on a daily basis.

3. It is possible to think thoughts and remember sensory experiences that are not captured with language that are just as accurate and memorable as those with language. What language does is make it easier to communicate those thoughts and experiences to other people.

4. Language also makes it possible to describe something that someone hasn't experienced before. If I say "It's the shiny red Moebius-loop sculpture that's about 6 feet tall" you'd probably recognize it if you saw it, because we have descriptive words for visual properties.
5. English is a shit language for describing smells. The proper words and concepts haven't been invented yet, in English at least.
6. Other languages are better at describing smells. For example Jahai.  https://t.co/jMxJroT1oT

7. English's lack of words for smells doesn't mean smells can't be named at all. And yet, so many clueless academics say shit like that eg. the quotes at the beginning of this paper about the Maniq, who also have better words for smell. https://t.co/DeLUkGMhBF

8. Luca Turin's theory of the human sense of smell, that it's like an electron tunneling spectrometer, is probably correct. (Although we don't have enough evidence to say so for sure. There's missing info about the human olfactory receptor.) https://t.co/YAXAYT5jYm

9. Luca Turin's likely correct on many topics related to smell, mentioned as asides in his book. For example, claims of a special connection between smell and sex are overblown. https://t.co/OWBTvAWFyX
10. There is such a thing as an "aftersmell". It's like an aftertaste, but for smells.

11. There ought to be better terminology for the time profile of experiencing a smell. Perfumers talk about top notes, middle notes, and end notes. Scientists handwave about vapor pressure. Neither captures or expresses all of the relevant information.
12. Smell can be connected to spatial reasoning and orientation. Humans can navigate by odor gradients. https://t.co/97U081QYox
13. Humans are good at smelling things. Animals, even dogs, are not necessarily superior at smelling particular things. https://t.co/uCVguZMG1O
14. Most things called "artificial nose" that are available now are not worthy of the name.

15. If artificial nose technology develops to the extent that the equivalent of what cameras and microphones do for sight and hearing is available to the average person, it will have as big an impact on society as the popularization of personal computers.
16. Geology and topography influence a smell landscape far more than I expected before I started paying attention.

17. It can be annoying when something that's important to you has not been made legible by society, including technology and language, and the only information available is sensory experiences. (For more on legibility, see this @ribbonfarm post https://t.co/TC3yhuOwYd )
18. Even though there are things like optical illusions, most of the time you can trust your senses.

19a. A lot of people will attempt to convince you something doesn't exist if it hasn't be measured with current technology. eg. Even though musicians could perceive differences in sound and touch between pianos and synthesizers using linear models of piano movement...

19b. ...only when high speed cameras showed non-linear motion of piano hammers did most scientists even consider that their models could be oversimplified. The musicians' sensory perception was correct all along. There are a lot of things like that.

20. Elementary schools ought to stop teaching the 5 senses model. Anyone who has the slightest interest in sensory perception knows there are more, such as proprioception. I blame Aristotle! https://t.co/qPhYw85FXG

21. Some large percentage of humans have the ability to perceive magnetic fields and to learn to control the magnetic fields in parts of the body such as hands to some extent. There haven't been enough scientific studies to show this yet, but that's what I predict.

22. The small number of studies that have been done so far on human ability to detect and control magnetic fields will turn out to understate the case. People will turn out to be more capable, not less capable, than the preliminary results.

23. Urban planning and bylaws don't do enough to let individuals control, customize, and experience a variety of sensory environments. It's easier to find somewhere loud than find somewhere quiet. You can't shut off your ears, so other people's noise matters.
24. Clean air is way more valuable and important to human health than you'd think from how North American society is set up.

25. There ought to be a parade for the people who phased out the coal power plants in Ontario. They are heroes who have saved thousands of lives. 600 people per year since 2014. https://t.co/UHNctcLLHb
26. There ought to be a parade for preventative heroes of all kinds, every year. The people who stop bad things from happening before they happen, so usually don't get much credit for it.

27. This is a neat PHD thesis. It uses distance measures on binary words of odor descriptors to figure out how humans perceive odors relative to one another. It concludes that apple goes between banana and cherry. https://t.co/PShmPlZOit

28. Reading the PHD thesis in this case is easier than reading the associated papers, since the background section explains things that biologists and computer scientists almost never say since they assume everyone already knows. https://t.co/PShmPlZOit
29. Humans in North America ought to pay more attention to what's upwind and downwind than they usually do.

30. If you experience sensations for which you don't have adequate words, pay attention to them and remember the raw sensory data as much as you can manage under the circumstances. It's better to do that than to apply ill-fitting words and concepts just because they are familiar.
31. If you acquire enough sensory data for which there are no adequate words, the shape of the missing concepts will become more clear over time.

32. Most people have more wordless raw sensory data than they realize in their memory already. Think of the smell of your grandmother's home...or something other place from childhood. You'd probably recognize it if you smelled it again, or encountered something similar.

33. One way to start noticing some nuances in flavour in beverages is to get different shapes of containers to drink them out of. eg. If you drink apple juice in a glass that opens out wide it will be a different experience than if you drink it in a glass that slopes inward.

34. Varieties of vegetables and fruits that are optimized for supermarkets have a different flavour profile from vegetables and fruits optimized for other things. Eating different varieties from farmers markets is a great way to train your palate.
35. Terroir is real. The soil and growing conditions matter. The differences can be subtle, some plants are more affected than others.
36. Paying attention to senses can feel good. Not having to pay attention to senses can also feel good, especially if you are in circumstances where that's an option. eg. in good enough health

37. User interfaces ought to take into account permanent, temporary or situational impairment or disabilities related to sensory experiences. The typical example: if designing with a one-handed user in mind, the other hand might be missing, injured, or occupied with a small child
38. Microsoft's inclusive design documents suffer from the 5-senses model. Aristotle has a lot to answer for. https://t.co/ANnxL5rpDT

39. A person ought to be able to use the user interfaces of computers or objects if they have permanent, temporary or situational impairment of senses beyond the 5-sense model such as proprioception, vestibular system.
